documents.content:
# Section 401 Water Quality Certification Fees (2025-26)

## What is 401 Certification?

Section 401 of the Clean Water Act requires state certification that activities needing federal permits will comply with state water quality standards.

## When 401 Certification is Required

- Projects requiring Army Corps of Engineers permits
- Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) licenses
- Other federal permits affecting waters

## Fee Categories

### Standard Certification (No Water Quality Impact)
- **Fee:** $500 minimum
- For projects with no potential water quality impact
- May increase if costs exceed base fee

### Fill and Excavation Projects

| Impact Area | Fee |
|-------------|-----|
| ≤ 1 acre | $1,000 |
| > 1 acre | $1,000 per acre (or part) |
| Maximum | $10,000 |

**Example:**
- 0.5 acre fill project = $1,000
- 3 acres fill project = $3,000
- 15 acres fill project = $10,000 (maximum)

### Dredging Projects

| Volume | Fee |
|--------|-----|
| < 10,000 cubic yards | $500 |
| 10,000 - 20,000 cy | $2,000 |
| > 20,000 cy | $2,000 + $250 per additional 5,000 cy |
| Maximum | $10,000 |

**Example:**
- 5,000 cy dredging = $500
- 15,000 cy = $2,000
- 50,000 cy = $2,000 + (6 × $250) = $3,500

### Public Sector/Restoration Projects
- May have modified fees
- Ecological restoration often discounted
- Contact your [Regional Water Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html)

## Fee Calculator

**Online Tool:** [CWA 401 Certification Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/)

Use calculator for informational estimates only (see also the [Region 8 fee schedule PDF](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/rwqcb8/water_issues/programs/401_certification/docs/401fee.pdf) for a sample regional document) - final fee determined by Water Board staff.

## Application Process

### Step 1: Determine Need
- Is federal permit required?
- Will activity affect waters of the state?

### Step 2: Calculate Fee
- Use online calculator
- Consult with Regional Board if unclear

### Step 3: Submit Application
- Complete application form
- Submit to appropriate Regional Water Board
- Include fee payment

### Step 4: Review Period
- Standard review: 60-90 days
- Complex projects: may take longer
- Additional information may be requested

## Pre-Application Meetings

- Recommended for complex projects
- Can clarify requirements
- May reduce review time
- Contact Regional Board to schedule

## Contact

**401 Program:** [CWA 401 Certification Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/)
**Regional Boards:** [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html)

## Take Action

1. **Check if 401 certification is needed** -- Visit the [CWA 401 Certification Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/) page to determine whether your project requires state water quality certification.
2. **Calculate your fee** -- Use the online fee tool and review the [Region 8 fee schedule (PDF)](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/rwqcb8/water_issues/programs/401_certification/docs/401fee.pdf) for example fee structures by project type.
3. **Find your Regional Board** -- Locate the correct Regional Water Quality Control Board for your project using the [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html).
4. **Schedule a pre-application meeting** -- For complex projects, contact your Regional Board early to clarify requirements and potentially reduce review time.
